AI_QUALITY_FAILURES.reasoning: ATLAS provided largely generic KB-style troubleshooting that the customer later stated had already been done, suggesting low adaptation to the case context. The early guidance also suggested using the UI to disable engines even though the ticket reported the UI section itself was throwing an exception and not loading, making parts of the advice potentially impractical. This is recall-first; while not definitively wrong, the quality appears mismatched and repetitive.
evidence: ATLAS: "Ensure that temporary folders (%temp% and C:\Windows\Temp) are not full... Add firewall exclusions for update servers..."
ATLAS: "If the problem persists, temporarily disable the Virus Scanning Engines one by one in the MailEssentials configuration UI (under Email Security > Virus Scanning Engines)"
Customer: "Please note that all the suggested steps have already been completed. Unfortunately, these actions did not resolve the issue"

AI_WALL_LOOPING.reasoning: The customer/partner explicitly requested a remote session with a technician, implying difficulty progressing via asynchronous scripted steps. While a human agent later engaged, the experience indicates a need to break out of the back-and-forth troubleshooting loop to live assistance; it’s not proven they were blocked from a human, but the request itself is a signal.
evidence: ADN Support (private): "our partner asked if we can plan a remote session together with one of your technicians... Could you please let us know when a technician would be available for a quick remote session?"
ADN Support (private): "The customer has been without email protection for about a week now, so we really need to get this issue fixed soon."

This indicates partial failure to incorporate already-provided constraints and progress.

It’s not explicitly shown that the customer confirmed resolution before closure, so there is some uncertainty but enough signal to flag recall-first.
